added_lines: #!/usr/bin/python # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright (c) 2022 OpenStack Foundation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import yaml from ansible.module_utils.basic import AnsibleModule from ansible_collections.openstack.cloud.plugins.module_utils.openstack import openstack_full_argument_spec from ansible_collections.openstack.cloud.plugins.module_utils.openstack import openstack_module_kwargs from ansible_collections.openstack.cloud.plugins.module_utils.openstack import openstack_cloud_from_module from tripleo_common.utils import roles as rolesutils ANSIBLE_METADATA = { 'metadata_version': '1.1', 'status': ['preview'], 'supported_by': 'community' } DOCUMENTATION = ''' --- module: tripleo_overcloud_role_list short_description: Retrieve list of overcloud roles version_added: "2.8" description: - "Retrieve list of overcloud roles" options: stack_name: description: - Name of the overcloud heat stack type: str author: - Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com> ''' RETURN = ''' role_list: description: Overcloud roles list returned: always type: list sample: - ''' EXAMPLES = ''' - name: Get Overcloud roles list tripleo_overcloud_role_list: stack_name: overcloud register: overcloud_role_list - name: Write data to output file copy: content: "{{ overcloud_role_list.role_list | to_yaml }}" dest: /path/exported-overcloud_role_list.yaml ''' def run_module(): result = dict( success=False, changed=False, error="", role_list=list() ) argument_spec = openstack_full_argument_spec( **yaml.safe_load(DOCUMENTATION)['options'] ) module = AnsibleModule( argument_spec, supports_check_mode=False, **openstack_module_kwargs() ) stack_name = module.params['stack_name'] try: roles_path = "/usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/roles" _, conn = openstack_cloud_from_module(module) result['role_list'] = rolesutils.get_roles_list_from_directory(roles_path) result['changed'] = bool(result['role_list']) module.exit_json(**result) except Exception as err: result['error'] = str(err) result['msg'] = ("Error getting role list from overcloud stack " "{stack_name}: %{error}".format(stack_name=stack_name, error=err)) module.fail_json(**result) def main(): run_module() if __name__ == '__main__': main()

commit_message:
libvirt: Add properties to set advanced QXL video RAM settings

This patch adds the following properties:

  - hw_video_ram_bar1      (sets libvirt's 'ram'    XML attribute)
  - hw_video_ram_bar2_ext  (sets libvirt's 'vram64' XML attribute)
  - hw_video_ram_vga       (sets libvirt's 'vgamem' XML attribute)

These properties can be used to specify the video RAM to provide for the
primary bar, the secondary bar extension (64 bit) and the VGA
framebuffer of a QXL graphics adapter.

All three properties are limited by the following extra_specs entries
for a flavor:

  - hw_video:ram_bar1_max_mb
  - hw_video:ram_bar2_ext_max_mb
  - hw_video:ram_vga_max_mb

Note that video RAM values for all three properties and limits are
specified in MB. If a property from above is used, make sure that its
corresponding limit is set in a referenced flavor; otherwise, a runtime
error occurs during instance creation.

Change-Id: If2a3e1686cb13af0e9e54f7aa79dd1696a135c91

commit_message:
Make ApiValidator to work with jsonschema>=4.0.0

As of Zed jsonschema version has been bumped to 4.14.0 in
upper-constraints, which means project should support running with
this version. This patch aims to fix ApiValidator that is not compatible
with new jsonschema.

Other deprecations, like FormatChecker.cls_checks decorator are left
intact and must be covered with follow-up patches.

We also move zuul queues to project scope as otherwise jobs do not
run due to config error.

We also replace iteritems with six method as iteritems have been dropped
from Python 3.

Change-Id: Ia8b69587aa9b3d04ffcdea7c6b97a8ae65f67534
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/28/864728/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def is_config(cls, instance):def is_simple_config(cls, instance):def is_flavor_type(cls, instance):class ApiValidator(jsonschema.Draft4Validator): TYPE_CHECKER = jsonschema.Draft4Validator.TYPE_CHECKER.redefine_many({ "configs": is_config, "flavor": is_flavor_type, "simple_config": is_simple_config, }) def __init__(self, schema, resolver=None, format_checker=jsonschema.FormatChecker()): schema, format_checker=format_checker)
deleted_lines: class ConfigTypeMeta(type): def __instancecheck__(cls, instance):class SimpleConfigTypeMeta(type): def __instancecheck__(cls, instance):@six.add_metaclass(ConfigTypeMeta) class ConfigsType(dict): pass @six.add_metaclass(SimpleConfigTypeMeta) class SimpleConfigsType(dict): pass class FlavorTypeMeta(type): def __instancecheck__(cls, instance):@six.add_metaclass(FlavorTypeMeta) class FlavorType(object): pass class ApiValidator(jsonschema.Draft4Validator): def __init__(self, schema): format_checker = jsonschema.FormatChecker() schema, format_checker=format_checker, types={ "configs": ConfigsType, "flavor": FlavorType, "simple_config": SimpleConfigsType, })

commit_message:
trivial: Remove use of kwargs

Make use of a "sentinel" object to allow us to remove the use of kwargs
and provide a more helpful docstring. With any luck, Python will support
these objects natively in a future release [1].

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0661/

Change-Id: I411c0393754c8fe8a6698f0d278b73f12209ace8
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/18/806918/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _SENTINEL = object() def rebuild( self, image, *, password=None, disk_config=None, preserve_ephemeral=False, name=None, meta=None, files=None, description=_SENTINEL, key_name=_SENTINEL, userdata=_SENTINEL, trusted_image_certificates=_SENTINEL, hostname=_SENTINEL, ): :param image: The :class:`Image` (or its ID) to re-image with. :param password: String to set as password on the rebuilt server. :param disk_config: Partitioning mode to use on the rebuilt server. Valid values are 'AUTO' or 'MANUAL' :param name: Something to name the server. :param meta: A dict of arbitrary key/value metadata to store for this server. Both keys and values must be <=255 characters. :param files: A dict of files to overwrite on the server upon boot. Keys are file names (i.e. ``/etc/passwd``) and values are the file contents (either as a string or as a file-like object). A maximum of five entries is allowed, and each file must be 10k or less. (deprecated starting with microversion 2.57) :param description: Optional description of the server. If None is specified, the existing description will be unset. (starting from microversion 2.19) :param key_name: Optional key pair name for rebuild operation. If None is specified, the existing key will be unset. (starting from microversion 2.54) :param userdata: Optional user data to pass to be exposed by the metadata server; this can be a file type object as well or a string. If None is specified, the existing user_data is unset. (starting from microversion 2.57) :param trusted_image_certificates: A list of trusted certificate IDs or None to unset/reset the servers trusted image certificates (starting from microversion 2.63) :param hostname: Optional hostname to configure for the instance. If None is specified, the existing hostname will be unset. (starting from microversion 2.90) :returns: :class:`Server` return self.manager.rebuild( self, image, password=password, disk_config=disk_config, preserve_ephemeral=preserve_ephemeral, name=name, meta=meta, files=files, description=description, key_name=key_name, userdata=userdata, trusted_image_certificates=trusted_image_certificates, hostname=hostname, ) def resize(self, flavor, *, disk_config=None): :param flavor: The :class:`Flavor` (or its ID) to resize to. :param disk_config: Partitioning mode to use on the rebuilt server. subject: Fixed using 'os_auth_ver' parameter when passed via --config
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-10-09 07:52:48.000000000', 'files': ['freezer/common/config.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/freezer/commit/a468477f4d45dbb60a9cf58f59a526d7e56d03aa', 'message': "Fixed using 'os_auth_ver' parameter when passed via --config

Although using 'os_auth_ver' parameter is deprecated, freezer-api (or
freezer-web-ui respectively) still uses it to generate configs for jobs.
Commit 50df2c8 introduced regression causing freezer-agent refusing to
start when config passed via '--config' contains 'os_auth_ver' parameter
(or any other deprecated option). The root cause is that loop (L568)
iterates through keys defined in config file passed via '--config'
therefore trying to call CONF.set_override with deprecated 'os_auth_ver'
as a first argument which causes oslo.config library to raise
KeyError: 'os-identity-api-version' as CONF.set_override is not expected
to be called with deprecated options. This simple patch adds call for
get for each key which may (correctly) raise NoSuchOptError for undefined
(and deprecated) keys, thus safely fallbacking to except routine.

Re-submitted.

Change-Id: Ia554d440b6256eab0f953ed9ad75cff1f040e6a1
(cherry picked from commit afbbaa2326d5e51ded7b06f7b1257e1a7807c152)
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed using 'os_auth_ver' parameter when passed via --config

Although using 'os_auth_ver' parameter is deprecated, freezer-api (or
freezer-web-ui respectively) still uses it to generate configs for jobs.
Commit 50df2c8 introduced regression causing freezer-agent refusing to
start when config passed via '--config' contains 'os_auth_ver' parameter
(or any other deprecated option). The root cause is that loop (L568)
iterates through keys defined in config file passed via '--config'
therefore trying to call CONF.set_override with deprecated 'os_auth_ver'
as a first argument which causes oslo.config library to raise
KeyError: 'os-identity-api-version' as CONF.set_override is not expected
to be called with deprecated options. This simple patch adds call for
get for each key which may (correctly) raise NoSuchOptError for undefined
(and deprecated) keys, thus safely fallbacking to except routine.

Re-submitted.

Change-Id: Ia554d440b6256eab0f953ed9ad75cff1f040e6a1
(cherry picked from commit afbbaa2326d5e51ded7b06f7b1257e1a7807c152)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer refs/changes/74/608874/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CONF.get(config_key)

commit_message:
Bump up Ansible supported versions to 5.x/6.x

This change bumps up the maximum supported Ansible version to 6.x
(ansible-core 2.13.x) and minimum to 5.x. This synchronises Kayobe with
Kolla Ansible.

Shebang has been removed from modules due to [1].

os_openstacksdk_version has been added as openstack cloud modules don't
support versions greater than 0.99.

[1]: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/76677

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/867546
Change-Id: Ibb00f6d079442a8509411ae8a71d74fd7bd8cccd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kayobe refs/changes/29/860529/36 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: kolla_ansible_venv_ansible: 'ansible>=5,<7.0'
deleted_lines: kolla_ansible_venv_ansible: 'ansible>=4,<6.0'

commit_message:
Change a list of files for leapp

* Remove repomap.csv as it was removed by leapp (f09c8add)
* Add an actual list of files
* Add retires and delay to improve resilience over networking issue

Change-Id: I710f2703b57de330cacf6d1e631180f4c0f13fba
(cherry picked from commit 10eec1d71651d64924386944a3953eb4982f212c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-upgrade refs/changes/35/867635/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: - 'repomap.csv'

subject: Fix pre_live_migration rollback
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-03-31 13:10:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a09d29b0bc537b9770d8dc4d7c1a6584798539f7', 'message': "Fix pre_live_migration rollback

During the pre live migration process, Nova performs most of the
tasks related to the creation and operation of the VM in the destination
host. That is done without interrupting any of the hardware in the source
host. If the pre_live_migration fails, those same operations should be
rolled back.

Currently nova is sharing the _rollback_live_migration for both
live and pre_live migration rollbacks, and that is causing the source
host to try to re-attach network interfaces on the source host where
they weren't actually de-attached.

This patch fixes that by adding a conditional to allow nova to do
different paths for migration and pre_live_migration rollbacks.

Closes-bug: #1944619
Change-Id: I784190ac356695dd508e0ad8ec31d8eaa3ebee56
(cherry picked from commit 63ffba7496182f6f6f49a380f3c639fc3ded9772)
(cherry picked from commit 379e54fe49b3343a0734c96574789614e3d83b49)
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-04-18 18:02:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/11350c7fac11c832b6d130747e3ecbdb8af4de2f', 'message': "Fix pre_live_migration rollback

During the pre live migration process, Nova performs most of the
tasks related to the creation and operation of the VM in the destination
host. That is done without interrupting any of the hardware in the source
host. If the pre_live_migration fails, those same operations should be
rolled back.

Currently nova is sharing the _rollback_live_migration for both
live and pre_live migration rollbacks, and that is causing the source
host to try to re-attach network interfaces on the source host where
they weren't actually de-attached.

This patch fixes that by adding a conditional to allow nova to do
different paths for migration and pre_live_migration rollbacks.

Closes-bug: #1944619
Change-Id: I784190ac356695dd508e0ad8ec31d8eaa3ebee56
(cherry picked from commit 63ffba7496182f6f6f49a380f3c639fc3ded9772)
(cherry picked from commit 379e54fe49b3343a0734c96574789614e3d83b49)
(cherry picked from commit c277636a96f4525ed6eb0530aa576f2156c8b99d)
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2022-04-18 19:09:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2b2a2aeb2e90c8721fc23c53da4b92f344b7e907', 'message': "Fix pre_live_migration rollback

During the pre live migration process, Nova performs most of the
tasks related to the creation and operation of the VM in the destination
host. That is done without interrupting any of the hardware in the source
host. If the pre_live_migration fails, those same operations should be
rolled back.

Currently nova is sharing the _rollback_live_migration for both
live and pre_live migration rollbacks, and that is causing the source
host to try to re-attach network interfaces on the source host where
they weren't actually de-attached.

different paths for migration and pre_live_migration rollbacks.

commit_message:
Fix pre_live_migration rollback

During the pre live migration process, Nova performs most of the
tasks related to the creation and operation of the VM in the destination
host. That is done without interrupting any of the hardware in the source
host. If the pre_live_migration fails, those same operations should be
rolled back.

Currently nova is sharing the _rollback_live_migration for both
live and pre_live migration rollbacks, and that is causing the source
host to try to re-attach network interfaces on the source host where
they weren't actually de-attached.

This patch fixes that by adding a conditional to allow nova to do
different paths for migration and pre_live_migration rollbacks.

Closes-bug: #1944619
Change-Id: I784190ac356695dd508e0ad8ec31d8eaa3ebee56
(cherry picked from commit 63ffba7496182f6f6f49a380f3c639fc3ded9772)
(cherry picked from commit 29b94aa34ad954e617c2a0d6df0809765dced188)

commit_message:
Backup CA key and certs by default

In order to avoid nasty consequences that may happen in case CA
certs gets accidentally rotated, we add backup option and set it to True
by default.

Change-Id: Ib188a56d25c44e5c201194b75d94de9fb027cfce

commit_message:
Only do snapshot on inactive nodes

The nodes must be taken out from Pacemaker cluster before taking a snapshot, one node at a time to not cause any downtimes. This will ensure that the database and the Ceph snapshots are consistent and we do not take the snapshot just during a write.

This behaviour can be deactivated using a parameter.

Also added the molecule data to use puppet lookup command

Change-Id: I3ea96ff2219733b3d8dd38680f2fa9eb50bb546b
(cherry picked from commit 626d4e1c99200faf03f27dd861daa855187d150c)

commit_message:
Add configuration options to set SPICE compression settings

blueprint: nova-support-spice-compression-algorithm
Change-Id: Iaa6e23cc5299a4a8f876fefdbff95fb05d19e94a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/88/849488/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================================== Add configuration options to set SPICE compression settings =========================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-support-spice-compression-algorithm This spec proposes to add SPICE-related options to a Nova configuration. These options can be used to enable and set the SPICE compression settings for libvirt (QEMU/KVM) provisioned instances. Note that those options are only taken into account if SPICE support is enabled (and the VNC support is disabled). Problem description =================== Sometimes, network bandwidth is limited especially if physical network hardware is involved in an OpenStack setup, e.g. if old network switches with limited uplink bandwidth are used. Nevertheless, a data-intensive transfer of console data between compute nodes and remote console clients should be possible in such an infrastructure. Here it would be beneficial if builtin compression settings could be activated for transport protocols (currently only SPICE) in order to transmit graphic-intense desktop content in networks with limited bandwidth. Use Cases --------- * An operator should be able to specify the SPICE compression algorithms and modes to lower network bandwidth for graphical console accesses. * A user should be able to access the graphical console of an instance as before, even from networks with limited bandwidth (e.g. from home). Proposed change =============== This spec proposes to add configuration options for all transport protocols in OpenStack that support the explicit activation of builtin compression settings. Currently only the integrated SPICE protocol allows the activation of various image [1]_ and video [2]_ compression settings to lower the network bandwidth while improving data transmission for graphic-intense desktops. Since SPICE is only supported by the libvirt hypervisor (through the QEMU backend), all other hypervisors and transport protocols are not affected by this proposed change. Libvirt already provides an automatic configuration of SPICE-related compression settings for the QEMU backend (see the ``spice`` documentation in the libvirt XML domain documentation [3]_). Therefore, the change only requires to make the libvirt hypervisor driver capable to generate a valid libvirt XML config with activated SPICE compression settings. The OpenStack configuration for the config generation should be stored in the ``spice`` configuration group of a Nova configuration. This configuration group should be extended with configuration options that are capable of specifying the SPICE-related compression settings (choose compression algorithms and toggle compression modes on/off). Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- The following SPICE-related options should be added to a Nova configuration: * | ``image_compression`` = [ ``auto_glz`` \| ``auto_lz`` \| ``quic`` \| ``glz`` \| ``lz`` \| ``off`` ]; | default = ``auto_glz`` * | ``jpeg_compression`` = [ ``auto`` \| ``never`` \| ``always`` ]; | default = ``auto`` * | ``zlib_compression`` = [ ``auto`` \| ``never`` \| ``always`` ]; | default = ``auto`` * | ``playback_compression`` = [ ``True`` \| ``False`` ]; | default = ``True`` * | ``streaming_mode`` = [ ``filter`` \| ``all`` \| ``off`` ]; | default = ``off`` The default value for each option is set to libvirt's default to preserve compatibility with older Nova configurations where those options are missing. Developer impact ---------------- None. Upgrade impact -------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: bahnwaerter Other contributors: None Feature Liaison --------------- Feature liaison: None Work Items ---------- * Add SPICE-related configuration options to the Nova configuration. * Create documentation for the SPICE-related configuration options. * Extend the SPICE config generation in the libvirt hypervisor driver. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= * Implement unit tests for each function to cover testing of added and changed methods. Documentation Impact ==================== * Extend the Nova configuration documentation and add documentation for the SPICE-related compression settings. References ========== .. [1] SPICE image compression: https://www.spice-space.org/spice-user-manual.html#_image_compression .. [2] SPICE video compression: https://www.spice-space.org/spice-user-manual.html#_video_compression .. [3] libvirt Domain XML format: https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#graphical-framebuffers History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Zed - Introduced

commit_message:
add spec for fqdn in hostname

Change-Id: Ie07a3fc54a94a667d58589f3ef61fe3c84547be1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/26/862626/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================ Allow FQDN in hostname field ============================ Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/fqdn-in-hostname enable end users to specify an FQDN as the instance hostname Problem description =================== Originally when nova was created the instance hostname was set from the instance display-name. Nova did not allow fqdns in the display name and explicitly blocked it but that was later removed as a bugfix. since this was not done as a spec or feature nova never provided an api gurentee that fqdns can be used when creating a server. following bug reports of undesireable interaction with designate we decided to extned the normalisation that removes non ascii alpha numeric charater to also remove period's form the hostname when initalising it form the display name. In the Xena release we also introduced configurable instance hostnames by exposing the host name filed directly in the api but maintained our prohibition on FQDNs. https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/xena/implemented/configurable-instance-hostnames.html This spec seeks to extend that filed to allow FQDNs to be used as the hostname of an instance. Use Cases --------- As an operator i want to allocate domain to my tenants and use automation to validate that the VMs are created with an FQDN that is derived from that domain. As a VNF vendor i want to set the value of /etc/hostname to an FQDN automatically when creating an instance via the api leveraging cloud-init or another tool without using user-data. Proposed change =============== - add a new api micoversion to opt into using an fqdn in the hostname field. - increase the character lenght limit on the host name filed form 63 to 255 - remove the rejection of "." and other leagal charaters in a fqdn. - change multi create instance format to prefix with an index instead of suffixing. This is allowed per section 2.1 of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc1123#page-13 """ The syntax of a legal Internet host name was specified in RFC-952 [DNS:4]. One aspect of host name syntax is hereby changed: the restriction on the first character is relaxed to allow either a letter or a digit. Host software MUST support this more liberal syntax. """ ..NOTE:: Today the instance.hostname field is propagated into the hostname field of the instance metadata. With this change the instance.hostname field can be an FQDN and that will also be propagated as done today without alteration other then the prefix for multi-create. Alternatives ------------ Nova could add a fqdn field e.g. openstack server create --fqdn ... this raises ambiguity of when to use --hostname vs --fqdn and requires a change to the data model to store the new field. Nova could add a domain filed e.g. openstack server create --hostname my-host --domain my.domain.com ... This is better then --fqdn but still required db and object changes for little benefit. Nova could block multi create. while this would avoid changing the hostname template form a suffix to prefix this in the new microversion it is a trivial code change and does not add much complexity vs multi create in general. Nova could try to propagate hostname change to neutron. This is seen as risky, complex and hard to understand. First nova was to propagate hostname changes to the port dns_name field it would only be able to do so on port that were created by nova not passed in. if we updated port that were passed in it could break excising use cases where an end user set the desired name. Second the floating ip dns_name is typically not the same as the instance FQDN. The instance hostname or FQDN is typically an internal name used in the application and the floating ip is used to expose a public name for the service. i.e. the instance might be called ``webserver.cloud.com`` where as the dns name of the floating ip might be ``blog.mysite.example.com``. given the two reasons above if nova was to propagate the name change we would need an attribute on the neutron port to opt into that behavior. Since this is only useful when using designate and designate already monitors nova notification endpoint to update endpoint using the designate-sink component, this functionality can be implemented using designate if they desire in the future. for these reasons updating the hostname in other service when its updated in nova is out of scope. ..NOTE:: As is done today, if the instance.hostname is updated on an instance it will be updated in the metadata service but not in the config derive if one is used. if the config-drive is ever regenerated such as via a cross cell resize then the new value will be available to the guest via the config drive. This does not change the behavior form before this change. Data model impact ----------------- None The database field is already large enough to hold any vlaid FQDN so no change are required to the db. The instance object declares the hostname field as a string and also requires no changes. REST API impact --------------- A new api microverion will be introduced to allow FQDNs in the hostname field. minor changes will be required to conditionally change the lenght restriction and disable some of the current validation when the new micorversion is used but the code will remain for older microverions. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Enduser will be able to set the hostname of there vm to an FQDN however without using a external service like designate to advertise that FQDN it may not be resolvable without manual intervention. Nova provides no garentee of uniqueness or reachability of the FQDN provided by the end user. As is the case today, nova will only set the dns_name on a neutron port once when the server is first created. If the end user updates the instance.hostname it will be upated in the nova db and become visible in the metadata api hostname field. It is out of scope of the nova project to propagate this hostname change to any neutron ports, floating ips or dns records. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers should be aware that unique FQDNs or hostnames cannot be enforced using the existing ``[DEFAULT]/osapi_compute_unique_server_name_scope`` config option as that provides uniqueness of the display name not the hostname. This spec does not introduce a way to force the hostnames or FQDNs to be unique in any scope. Developer impact ---------------- osc should be extended to support the new microversion. Upgrade impact -------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: notartom Other contributors: None Feature Liaison --------------- Feature liaison: sean-k-mooney Work Items ---------- remove api restriction update api sample tests update osc Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= This can be entirly tested with api/functional tests. Documentation Impact ==================== The api ref will be updated References ========== None History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - 2023.1 Antelope - Introduced

commit_message:
Enable floating search bar

Depending on the size of the datatable, sometimes, the search
bar is "hidden" due to the user scrolling. To make the
interface more user-friendly, it is interesting that both
the search bar and the sidebar are always displayed. Therefore,
this patch is introducing changes to always pin the search bar
and the sidebar at the top of the page.

Closes-Bug: #1928678
Change-Id: I9186a4fa1dd2a16f75464ff3bb1c0c9b76a12cc7

commit_message:
Adds regression test for bug LP#1944619

Related-bug: #1944619
Closes-bug: #1964472
Change-Id: Ia208ef0dd0bab1c59d025234f4da7537c39cda61
(cherry picked from commit 2ddb8bf53fdf9a17c09afc4987ab6efe8ba97696)
(cherry picked from commit 3402aa7a53a48e6abc0fb8a2620cd449fd3f75fe)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/32/838332/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2021, Canonical, Inc. All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import fixtures from nova import exception as nova_exceptions from nova.tests.fixtures import libvirt as fakelibvirt from nova.tests.functional import integrated_helpers from nova.tests.functional.libvirt import base class TestRollbackWithHWOffloadedOVS( base.LibvirtMigrationMixin, base.ServersTestBase, integrated_helpers.InstanceHelperMixin ): """Regression test for bug LP#1944619 Assert the behaviour observed in bug LP#1944619 caused by the live migration cleanup code being used to cleanup pre-live migration failures. When SRIOV devices are in use on a VM, that will cause the source host to try to re-attach a VIF not actually de-attached causing a failure. The exception mocked in pre_live_migration reproduce an arbitrary error that might cause the pre-live migration process to fail and rollback_live_migration_at_source reproduce the device re-attach failure. """ api_major_version = 'v2.1' microversion = 'latest' ADMIN_API = True def setUp(self): super().setUp() self.start_compute( hostname='src', host_info=fakelibvirt.HostInfo( cpu_nodes=1, cpu_sockets=1, cpu_cores=4, cpu_threads=1)) self.start_compute( hostname='dest', host_info=fakelibvirt.HostInfo( cpu_nodes=1, cpu_sockets=1, cpu_cores=4, cpu_threads=1)) self.src = self.computes['src'] self.dest = self.computes['dest'] lib_path = "nova.virt.libvirt.driver.LibvirtDriver" funtion_path = "rollback_live_migration_at_source" mock_lib_path = "%s.%s" % (lib_path, funtion_path) self.libvirt_mock = self.useFixture( fixtures.MockPatch(mock_lib_path, side_effect=fakelibvirt.libvirtError( defmsg="libVirt duplicated dev error"))) funtion_path = "pre_live_migration" mock_lib_path = "%s.%s" % (lib_path, funtion_path) self.useFixture(fixtures.MockPatch( mock_lib_path, side_effect=nova_exceptions.DestinationDiskExists( path='/var/non/existent')) ) def test_rollback_pre_live_migration(self): self.server = self._create_server(host='src', networks='none') # Live migrate the instance to another host self._live_migrate(self.server, migration_expected_state='error', server_expected_state='MIGRATING') # FIXME(erlon): In the current behavior, # rollback_live_migration_at_source is called if an error happens # during the pre_live_migration phase on the destination and therefore # triggers the observed bug. rollback_live_migration_at_source should # *not* be called for when errors happen during pre_live_migration # phase. self.libvirt_mock.mock.assert_called_once()

Currently the flavor creation form always check for the uniqueness
of the UUID field, even when it is set to "auto". That means that if

commit_message:
Fix flavor id auto generation

Currently the flavor creation form always check for the uniqueness
of the UUID field, even when it is set to "auto". That means that if
we create a flavor with UUID value of "auto", the check will fail.

This patch disable the check when UUID is automatically generated.

Change-Id: Ie31307d67cf3857e3bb80c124e92c81e0c6a2982
(cherry picked from commit af7e6c4f75299b9e47db059dc7ddbaf2e0b1a3fc)

commit_message:
Update tox.ini for tox 4

Update tox.ini to be compatible with tox 4
It should also be retrocompatible with tox 3

Change-Id: I3625c77ddc28f6bb7f310be215ca347076762d90

commit_message:
Add a shard key

Story: 2010378
Change-Id: If992e3d8f512fab94334b7193a83a4b46973a0fc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/03/861803/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================== Shard Key Introduction ====================== After much discussion and attempts to remedy the scalability issues other services, the consensus ha ssemingly been reached to introduce a sharding model wich would allow API consumsers to map and lock on to specific sets of baremetal nodes, regardless of if the relationship is semi-permenant or entirely situational. Only the consumer of the information performing processing can make that determination, and it is up to Ironic to try and provide the substrate capabilities to efficiently operate against it's API. Problem description =================== The reality is Ironic can be used at some absurd scales, and while *most* operators of Ironic either run multiple smaller Ironic deployments, some operate at a scale where external operations polling ironic may not be scaled in ideal configurations. It is also easy for misconfigurations to be made where performance can become degraded, which is because the scaling model and limits are difficult to understand easily. This is observable with the operation of Nova's Compute process when running the ``nova.virt.ironic`` driver. It is operationally easy to get into situations where one is attempting to support thousands of baremetal nodes, with too few ``nova-compute`` processes. This specific situation leads to the process attempting to take on more work than it was designed to handle. Recently we discovered a case, while rooted in misconfiguration, where the same basic scaling issue exists with ``networking-baremetal`` where it is responsible for polling and updating physical network mappings in Neutron. The same basic case, a huge amount of work, and multiple processes. The root issue is the software consuming Ironic's data needs to be able to self-delineate the overall node set and determine the local separation points for sharding the nodes. The challenge, from what has been done previously, is the previous model required downloading the entire data set to build a hash ring from. Where things are also complicated, is Ironic has an operational model of a ``conductor_group``, which is intended to help model a physical grouping or operational constraint. The challenge here is that conductor groups are not automatic in any way, shape, or form. Proposed change =============== Overall the idea, is to introduce a ``shard_group`` field on the node object. And then introduce a database table which is updated via a periodic task, to allow API consumers to discover the available shard keys from a periodic programattic survey of the keys. A ``shard_leader`` column would be added to the conductor table, to allow a single conducto to take on, and handle the role of ensuring the newly added ``shards`` table. The aformentioned periodic task would only run on this leader conductor, and would be charged with keeping the ``shards`` table in a "lazy, evantually state" This way we're not constantly updating the count. Node creation logic would then be able to consult the shard's table and allocate a node to a random shard, or a less-utilized shard if not otherwise specified. Example 1: * Shard-10, Shard-11, and Shard-13 exists, and all nodes are assigned to these shards. In this case, substantial numbers which would imply an imbalance. * Operator creates a node with a ``shard_group`` of "Shard-14" * Operator then creates multiple new nodes, which auto-create with "Shard-14" as the ``shard_group``. Eventually the imbalance is self-addressed. Example 2: * Shard-10, Shard-11, and Shard-13 exist. * 3 new nodes are created by an operator, and new nodes are randomly assigned across the three shards. We *can* provide a means to pre-set the shard, but ultimately it is still optional for Ironic, and the shard *exists* for the user. Which means, if someone begins to set shards after the fact, the designated ``shard_leader`` needs to take on a role of updating nodes which do not have a ``shard_group`` set. In order to facilitate the usage ``/v1/nodes`` and ``/v1/ports`` would be updated to accept a ``shard`` parameter in the query to allow for API consumers to automatically scope limit their data set and self determine how ot reduce the workset. For example, ``networking-baremetal`` may not care about assignment, it just needs to reduce the localized workset. Whereas, ``nova-compute`` needs the field to remain static, that is unless ``nova-compute`` or some other API consumer were to request the ``shard_group`` to be updated on a node. In terms of access controls, we would also add a new RBAC policy to restrict changes such that the system itself or a appropriately scoped (i.e. administrative) user can change the field. In this model, conductors do not care about the shard key, except for the ``shard_leader`` who is in charge of driving consistency and handling record keeping. Alternatives ------------ This is a complex solution to allow simplified yet delineated usage, and there are numerous other options for specific details. Ultimately, each item should be discussed, and considered. One key apsect, which has been recognized thus far, is that existing mechanisms can be misused to achieve this. Example ``conductor_group``, ``owner``, ``lessee`` all allow for filtering of the node result set. Consensus seems to be that usage of the fields, while in part may be useful and advisable in some cases, it doesn't solve the general need to be able to allow clients to self delineate *without* first downloading the *entire* node list first. Which in itself, is a known scaling challenge. Data model impact ----------------- Node: Addition of a ``shard_group`` column/value field, default None. Conductor: Addition of a ``shard_leader`` column/value field, default None. A new table will be added, ``shards`` a simplified interface of two columns. A shard key value and count value. It will not have a object table, it will be intended to be an *as simplified and as performant* as possible processing of the result set. Also, only node will be chartered with keeping the data up to date, so no need for object symatics. A ``shard_leader`` election process will need to be determined, likely involving a lockout timer and an intermediate state before the election process completes. To facilitate this, database migrations, and data model sanity checking will need to be added to ``ironic-status`` as part of the upgrade checks. State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- GET /v1/nodes?shard=VALUE Returns a subset of nodes limited by shard key. GET /v1/ports?shard=VALUE Returns a subset of ports, limited by the shard key. GET /v1/shards Returns a JSON representing the shard keys and counts of nodes utilizing the shard. {"Shard-10": 352, "Shard-11": 351, "Shard-12": 35, 'None': 921} Visibility wise, the new capabilities will be restricted by API micro-version. Access wise this field would be restricted in use to ``system-reader``, ``project-admin``, and future ``service`` roles by default. A specific RBAC policy would be added for access to this endpoint. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- Typically, but not always, if there are any REST API changes, there are corresponding changes to python-ironicclient. If so, what does the user interface look like. If not, describe why there are REST API changes but no changes to the client. "openstack baremetal" CLI ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A ``baremetal shard list`` command would be added. A ``--shard-group`` node level parameter for ``baremetal node set`` woul also be added. "openstacksdk" ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A SDK method would be added to get a shard list, and existing list methods would be checked to ensure we can query by shard. RPC API impact -------------- None anticipated at this time. Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ Chances are, if this change affects the REST or Driver APIs, it will also affect the Nova driver in some way. If this requires a functional change in Nova, chances are the Nova team will require a spec to discuss the changes to their project as well. Provide a link to that here, or a justification for why that is not needed. Questions which need to be addressed in this section include: * What is the impact on Nova? * If this change is enabling new functionality exposed via Nova, this section should cite the relevant components within other Nova drivers that already implement this. * Ironic and Nova services must be upgradable independently. If the change affects existing functionality of the nova.virt.ironic driver, how will an upgrade be performed? How will it be tested? .. TODO:: Potentail idea, nova could *evacuate* into a new shard key. Ramdisk impact -------------- None Security impact --------------- The ``shard_group`` key would be API user settable, as long as sufficient API access exists in the RBAC model. The ``/v/shards`` endpoint would also be restricted based upon the RBAC model. No other security impacts are anticipated. Other end user impact --------------------- None Anticipated Scalability impact ------------------ This model is anticipated to allow users of data stored in Ironic to be more scalable. No impacts to Ironic's scalability are generally anticipated above and beyond a leader election process being needed for shard count management. Performance Impact ------------------ In this model of use, the scalability of the chosen/elected ``leader`` would be slightly reduced, however the occassional periodic task is presently anticipated to be lightweight, as we can request a unique sorted count list of ``shard_group`` values set. The prime driver behind a *single* conductor doing so is to avoid deadlock conditions and not place responsibility on other conductors. Other deployer impact --------------------- It *is* recognized that operators *may* wish to auto-assign or auto-shard the node set. It is presently anticipaed that we either should do this automatically where pertinant, *OR* require a manual command to be executed which handles node locking and shard key setting. This may require a new configuration option, to determine the desirable Developer impact ---------------- None anticipated Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <IRC handle, email address, or None> Other contributors: <IRC handle, email address, None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in Ironic, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Ironic, document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? * Does this feature target specific hardware? If so, is it a common standard (eg IPMI) or a vendor-specific implementation (eg iLO)? Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc)? Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== Care must be taken to support our users by not breaking backwards compatibility with either REST API or Driver API changes. * If your proposal includes any changes to the REST API, describe how existing clients will continue to function when interacting with an upgraded API server. * If your proposal includes any changes to the Driver API, describe how existing driver implementations will continue to function when loaded by a conductor running with the new driver base class. * Describe what testing you will be adding to ensure that backwards compatibility is maintained. * If deprecating an existing feature or API, describe the deprecation plan, and for how long compatibility will be maintained. Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs team of this change? Some changes might require donating resources to the docs team to have the documentation updated. Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

subject: Discussion: Options to address ironic driver rebalance

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-05-17 01:14:37.000000000', 'files': ['specs/zed/approved/ironic-fix-management-issues.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/d7665380e0791a0ec00a11e196d3f70ec79ce37c', 'message': 'Discussion: Options to address ironic driver rebalance

A series of bugs is rooted in the fact that ultimately unprovisioned

Where things go sideways, is when you have an outage for a node which

commit_message:
Discussion: Options to address ironic driver rebalance

A series of bugs is rooted in the fact that ultimately unprovisioned
baremetal nodes can freely rebalance between instances of a
nova-compute service.

Where things go sideways, is when you have an outage for a node which
is deployed already. You loose the ability to manage it because the
Instance calls occur using the host field on the Instance object.

Similar issue exists for ComputeNode, even though they are automatically
deleted in some cases, a possibility of still orphaning exists and
can create bad things.

Ultimately both of these cases require manual database edits today to
remedy, and are an operator pain point.

This area of the code, and the ultimately artificial limitation which
exists in the code is the root for a number of other issues because
the state of the universe is not fixed when it changes.

The purpose of this change is to ultimately attempt to reach some
sort of consensus and understanding on a path forward, even though
realistically this is a number of bugs which impacts operators.

Change-Id: I1ecde567ad3dfdc6ad82702d7ede00e4518cba95
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/15/842015/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Options to fix reblance ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/ironic-instance-change-host Prior discussion: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/815789/ The Ironic virt driver within Nova is an oddity of sorts and creates what can be described as an "impedence mismatch". In the normal operating case of the driver, it proxies calls through to the ``ironic-api`` surface, and as a compute service it reads inventory information from that API surface and supplies it to Nova itself in order to enable scheduling. The conundrum with this interaction is operational requirements and ultimately usage does differ from the normally expected pattern of a hypervisor. The result, is this "impedence mismatch" has resulted in what can only be described as an entire class of bugs that result in non-ideal operator experience. While this is a specification document, and there is a big picture hope of backporting. Because of the complexity and future direction, the desire was to treat this more as a specification document to build consensus and attempt to fully understand the mechanics, and hopefully come up with some number of solutions. Terminology & Meaning ===================== It is recognized by many that this is a complex problem, where specific words which carry different meaning in their community contextes. As such we are including a table to reference, and we will endevour to not just use a word as "node" alone without specific and direct context. In part this is because the Tooz hash ring code has specific terminology as well. Tooz ---- Tooz is a library within the OpenStack community which contains a consistent hash ring code base. Small, and ultimately mighty, it allows for an input value to be distributed across a set of services in a reliable fashion as long as the list of input nodes does not change. If it changes composition for a short period of time, and then returns to it's prior state, the distribution of work resulting is ultimately the same as before. An example of this being used to great success is in Ironic itself, where a consistent hash ring has been used for many years to distribute physical machines across compute nodes. This pattern realistically only changes as additional ``ironic-conductor`` services come online, or disappear. Concept Reference Table ----------------------- +--------------------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | Concept of use/operation | In Ironic/Virt Driver | In Tooz Hash Ring | +--------------------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | Responsible entity | nova-compute service | nodes | +--------------------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | Objects mapped for Tooz | nova-compute services | objects/data | +--------------------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | Baremetal Nodes | node and ComputeNode | Not Applicable - | | | | allocates a node | | | | to a node | +--------------------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | Tooz get_nodes() returns | nova-compute service | Node to allocate | | | | the supplied input | | | | to | +--------------------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ Problem description =================== Ultimately, the problem which exists is the impedence mismatch in some ways due to the underlying patterns of use. As a single nova-compute service operating as a hypervisor for virtual machines, you may have a couple hundred virtual machines. In the case of Ironic, It's API surface may be concealing hundreds, thousands, or in the largest operators in the world, hundreds of thousands of physical baremetal nodes. Obviously, one cannot expect a single nova-compute service to serve as a command and inventory proxy for much more than a thousand phsyical baremetal nodes. Known performance, and locking issues make this undesirable and in operator spheres because updating internal inventory into Nova is a known high-overhead operation which which also prevents commands from being proxied through to Ironic nodes. And so, a very long time ago, an effort started which resulted in an ability to run multiple nova-compute services talking to the same Ironic API endpoint. This effort, while successful, is where the root of our issues originate. To make this happen, a consistent hash ring is generated using Tooz which is populated utilizing the list of "online" nova-compute services. This is ideally re-evaluated every time an internal cache of nodes, in this specific case, baremetal nodes, is updated from Ironic. Where this entire thing begins to loose traction is the original code never expected the operational environment to ever change, which is simply not true of any infrastructure operator. Inventory changes. Infrastructure hosting services and components change, and ultimately need to be changed as an environment grows and needs to address performance issues or prevent potential reliability risks. The practical net result of the static expectation, is that the code expected the host the nova-compute service ran on, to remain forever, and be forever useable and addressable. In a cloud with a high rate of churn, this might have been slightly acceptable, but experience in the community is physical nodes tend to be reused and reallocated quickly, *or* exist for quite a long time as individual instances in Nova. Combine with normal cycling of services, through even basic operations like software updates, a churn was created which also introduced yet another class of bugs. Granted, the static expectation makes all the sense in the world if the host running the nova-compute service is a hypervisor with virtual machines. The crux of this issue, is ultimately that the hash ring is used to determine the distribution of nodes for the internal cache of the driver, which also drives scheduling updates, which can result in Compute Nodes, being deleted in some cases. And when a failure has occured, or something as mundane as a hostname accidently chagned on the host, the instances which were deployed at that time are no longer managable. Again, it cannot be stressed enough, this is a complex set of issues, and a large number of bugs going back a very long time revolve around this issue. This is also not the first time some have sought to fix this issue, but hopefully we will reach an understanding and consensus. Before we proceed further, we need to be congizent of the actual bugs we know about at present. Launchpad Bug #1730834 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1730834 This one of two fundimental bugs which exist, where in operational terms one nova-compute service does not take over responsibility for the deployed baremetal instances of a nova-compute service which has gone down. From an operational perspectie, it is reasonable to expect the service to do so where it is just a command proxy. It does this because only baremetal nodes which are **not deployed** as instances are considered for incorporation into the node cache *as well as* baremetal nodes supplied by matching the ``nova-compute`` service's hostname for an instance list. Effective result is, we *both* loose the deployed instance in record updates and tracking. The ComputeNode record can then also be deleted, and there is sadness. Granted, the ComputeNode record is now recreated. Launchpad Bug #1825876 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1825876 While slightly misleading, this is the second fundimental bug which exists. The bug's original author talks about stopping an ``ironic-conductor`` service, when in reality they are talking about stopping a ``nova-compute`` service and obseving the expected and resulting impact to the hypervisor list. This is in part because the hypervisors (Compute Nodes) are pruned out due to logic in the Compute Manager which evaluates the ComputeNode ``host``, and if it doesn't match a working hypervisor, then the ComputeNode object is deleted from the database. Operationally this is a case for an ``available`` baremetal node in Ironic *and* the internal driver cache is updated as a result of the rebalance operation of a nova-compute service going down due to timing out it's heartbeat to the database. This is also what contributes to bug another bug about spurious errors in the ``nova-compute`` logs "during" a rebalance operation. This can be found as `Bug 1841476<https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1841476>`_. Red Hat Bugzilla #2017980 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2017980 This is a Red Hat bugzilla entry which is largely a result of the behavior of both the two previously noted Luanchpad bugs and "normal life" in any operations environment. Nothing takes over for the instances deployed on Baremetal Nodes, at least in terms of a ``nova-compute`` service. In essence, you loose the ability to manage the instance, unless "database surgery" is performed to update the nova Instance object's host field to match the running compute hostname. This is also somewhat a side-effect of information technology processes as *new* physical servers being upgrading, or entirely replacing *failed* physical are often setup, configured, and operated with a different hostname. The old hostname no longer exists, and rightfully so, would only create confusion if someone were to find it and go look for it in a Configuration Management Data Base or Hardware Inventory. This ultimately is both an operator and user experience headache, and a maintenance risk as right now, the only way to recover the ability to manage the deployed instances, is to update the host field on the records. Launchpad Bug #1933955 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1933955 Ultimately, this bug is a result of the overall situation with the driver *combined* with the code driver not being updated to explicitly filter baremetal nodes by view nor the driver's perception based upon an instance's ``instance_id`` value. Because of the view resources are in essence forever out of sync if the environment has changed or evolved, a relatively misleading error message is logged by each nova-compute service, every time the compute manager syncs the power states. Additionally, the API call used for this is rather inefficent, and this can be reconciled from local cache if the cache is correct. Use Cases --------- The issues which we have identified are very much a result of use cases and use expectations which are not unreasonable. * As an operator, I expect a partial service or operational failure to be able to be recovered from automatically or as a result of existing systems management tooling. I don't expect to add new processes or perform manual intervention after the fact. * As an operator, I want to be able to scale up/down my Ironic nova-compute services and replace a failed Ironic nova-compute service in operation without manual intervention. * As an end-user, I expect to be able to continue to manage my Bare Metal instances and remain unaware of any outage within my provider's cloud. * As an operator, I don't want to have to deal with extra fallout from a minor misconfiguration or infrastruture state change months after the fact when my user cannot power-off their Bare Metal Instance. Proposed change =============== Or perhaps, multiple proposed possibilities. Just fix the fields as we "rebalanance* as a result of the hash ring changing ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- In 2019, this was `proposed previously <https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/671534>`_, in part. The author posted it as a proof of concept and indicated they didn't have time to work on it unfortunately. The idea is in essence the same as the most recent `recent bugfix proposal <https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/813897>`_, although the difference is the newer proposal sought to remedy *both* Instance objects as well as ComputeNode objects in the database. Originally this was spread across multiple patches, but nova contributors requested the fixes be consolidated. Additionally, `another proposal<https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/815789>`_ was incidently filed as a specification, which propsoes in essence the same action as the original bugfix with one additional idea which has been noted below in the appropriate section. The overall idea was to: 1) Be intentional around hash ring and cache updates, only process if *when* the structure actually changes and only process what we "own" 2) Correct the caching issues that kept nodes sticky to the cache and would result in them moving after a structural change to the environment has occured. i.e. Instance deployed while compute was down, cache is influenced by that "deployed while down" relationship, and as soon as the Bare Metal Node is in ``available`` state to be reallocated, it would stay in one ``nova-compute`` service's node's cache until the next rebalance/cache rebuild, and meanwhile suddenly appear on another ``nova-compute`` service. The net effect of this would have been "only cache baremetal nodes matching the hash ring", and "any node we get explicitly asked about over RPC until the next cache refresh". 3) Reconcile the Nova ``instance.host`` field so instances can be managed through the surviving or new ``nova-compute`` instances. 4) Reconcile the Nova ``ComputeNode.Host`` field to allow reporting to be accurate and avoid the "If the ``nova-compute`` instance's host is missing, automatically start deleting records of of the down ComputeNodes, which prevents ComputeNodes from being deleted in the Ironic use case. The deletion being a major source of operator frustration, as cases can occur which require explicitly restarting the ``nova-compute`` service to remedy the record keeping situation. 5) Assume time has passed, and retieve the latest list of ``nova-compute`` service instances *before* changing records, in order to skip re-mapping an Instance or ComputeNode object's host field record if the original ``nova-compute`` service has returned to the cluster. In other words, Don't remap if likely source of our rebalance has re-appeared in the specific record's case we are evaluating. 6) Have something we can backport. Concerns ~~~~~~~~ Discussion of this potential solution has raised a few concerns. * This solution makes use of writing to remoted objects ove the RPC bus as the nova-compute service does not have direct database access in Nova's architecture. * Concerns have been voiced that two compute services can race each other believing they are authoratative based upon their perspective. * This is a distinct possibiliy in the case of an entire cloud's Nova compute services being started after an elongated hard outage. * In such a scenario, each ``nova-compute`` process would start with it's view of the data, but prior to reconciling it would check online compute nodes. In such cases, the code is designed to skip updating Instance and ComputeNode objects as a re-evaluation is bound to occur on all nodes as their starting perception was only partial view due to the startup. * Concerns have been voiced about ?aggregate? data calcuation/records .. NOTE:: This was raised in high bandwith calls to discuss concerns but was not captured. If a nova contributor could help clarify, it would be greatly appreciated. * Automatic reconcilation seems to generally go against Nova maintainers operational use model where for any such action, which is that an "instance" must be "evacuated" from a "failed" ComputeNode. * From a perspective of operators, this means an explicit decision has to be made of where to put the additional workload, meaning in essence the ``nova-compute`` process workload and responsibilities would require substantial manual intervention to have an even distribution of baremetal hardware nodes associated to ``nova-compute`` processes. * Additionally, formally encoding logic to treat an ``Instance.host`` field to influence node caching, ultimately means we are not actually fixing the issues related to cache handling and assignment. .. NOTE:: Additional concern, when discussed, it was mentioned that a new instnace is created. Is the instance_id static? If not, evacuate would be a hard break because instance_id is static on ironic side while the node is provisioned. * Database locking has been raised as a general concern. As updates would be row level changes in the tables, and row level locking applies in that case, it may not be a huge concern when combined with a general usage. .. NOTE:: A distinct possibility is we *could* explicitly block resource tracker calls of get_available_nodes from the cache *while* we're processing the hash ring update, which would block anintermediate state. We could just have a flag on the driver and raise the ?VirtDriverNotReady? exception? * A worry about attempting to take over the management of the same node has been raised, which mainly exists in cold-start situations when all computes have been started at once and the last ``nova-compute`` service's heartbeat was recorded >90 seconds ago. * Realistically, concurrent startup is a potential, but does not seem to pan out in an operational practicality with this case as Ironic itself does the exact same thing upon startup. The ironic community really has not had any operational or performance complaints regarding that aspect. * The proposed patch is also authored with an understanding that in larger deployments, it takes a substantial amount of time to retrieve the list of instances *and* the list of Bare Metal nodes from Ironic. Both of which are required to generate the cache of nodes for which the ``nova-compute`` process uses for both performance reasons as well as to guide what it is responsible for with the hash ring. The patch explicitly re-queries the running ``nova-compute`` services and then executes two sanity checks: * If we are the ``nova-compute`` service host which matches the record, then no action is required. * If the listed nova-compute service is in the most recently updated list of nova-compute services *and* it is not known to the hashring, then skip updating the ``host`` fields Add a conditional around fixing the fields and have it be a default ------------------------------------------------------------------- Based on the previous idea, would be to guard off the rebalance logic and make it opt-in. This has an advantage allowing larger operators to opt in to when they absolutely need to handle these cases. The Ironic community has done quite a bit of this for infrastructure operators as no one operator's environment or use pattern is the same, and generally we have found them appreciative when the capability is just an option waiting for them, as opposed to needing a fix. With this, we might not be able to perfectly fix the cache, but overall the experience would be better for larger operators who encounter the listed bugs on a fairly regular basis. Concerns ~~~~~~~~ * Some Nova contributors seem to have a hard objection to any configuration option being present being available for this. This was not elaborated upon in in discussion. .. NOTE:: Can we get a written rational for why we can't just guard off with a config option? Only rebalance a node's assets if it is Compute is DOWN and Disabled -------------------------------------------------------------------- This proposal builds upon the first proposal, except it is to add logic which requires an already "DOWN" ``nova-compute`` service to be explicitly disabled by an operator before the Bare Metal Nodes, ComputeNodes, and Instances it is responsible for managing are "rebalanced". Concerns ~~~~~~~~ * Additional ``nova-compute`` services being added to an environemnt would not be able to take on the additional resource management/tracking overhead without manual intervention, or through resource attrition, potentially also tickling other resource tracking issues under the problem space of "baremetal node disappears", and "new node looking like that other node just appeared, potentially incurring an additional workload within other areas of Nova. Locking the Instance/Compute node records ------------------------------------------ This proposal would be to somehow lock the Instance/Compute node records in something such as a DLM or on a specific topic on the message bus. .. NOTE: We quickly exited this idea in discussions, possibly due to feasibility of backport concerns, so it remained vauge. Concerns ~~~~~~~~ * This may not be backportable. * This may not be able to play nicely in a live environment undergoing an upgrade, at least without substantial testing. Make the nova conductor handle assignments and assign nodes ----------------------------------------------------------- The idea here is just to not have this problem and to shift everything to be assigned out of the ``nova-conductor`` process. A major plus is this, while complex, would address multithreading and record locking/concurrency concerns on db records by allowing a singular lock to be used per node or for the overall process. Concerns ~~~~~~~~ * This surely would not be backportable, in other words forward only. * This doesn't really fix any cache related issues, and mainly focuses only on the assignment of responsibility for management continuity of mangement. Node/ComputeNode/Instance to a specific ``nova-compute`` service. * This would functionally create a single point of operational failure and data calculation, in a area of processing which operators have found problematic with distributed ``nova-computes`` processes. * In other words, we may also create more problems than we would fix. Align configuration and use a different shard key to break apart the hash ring ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ .. NOTE:: Under initial discussion Provide a ?nova-manage? command to fix the db, kind of cleanup the cache code ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- One discussed solution involved in essence, focusing the record fixes around manual operator invocation of an non-internal tool to fix the records. An advantage in this is because the way the hash ring works being a division of items, in this case baremetal nodes, across a list of known hosts, a single host *could* assert new records and perform the reconcilation for all nodes as long as it has an equal level of access to the database *and* is able to retrieve the list of Bare Metal nodes. .. NOTE:: It occurs to me that we could just always say the first ironic compute is the leader and can do these things, and keep all of the other computes as purely read/only. We could still kind of fix the cache in the next pass the remote compute node. Concerns ~~~~~~~~ * Not automatic, still requires manual intervention, but could fully remedy records while allowing rebalancing to still be a thing with the hashring. * Cache would still need to be hinted based upon instance state, at least for deployed nodes. * The hash ring would realistically need to be allowed to change/evolve, but Make a single nova-compute "the leader", and have it do it the reconcile ------------------------------------------------------------------------ .. NOTE:: This is a fresh idea that came up while typing out one of the discussed items. Distinct possibility this could work with just the local information already present in the DB/Configuration. Then again it may only work with just ironic deployments. Research required. Alternatives ------------ Not Applicable, multiple solutions proposed above. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- To be determined. Solution dependent. Performance Impact ------------------ To be determined. Solution dependent. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- None Anticipated Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: TBD Other contributors: TBD Feature Liaison --------------- TBD Work Items ---------- A complete list will be determined by the resulting disucssion and consensus, if any. * Somehow reach consensus * Fix this issue Dependencies ============ None Anticipated Testing ======= To be determined based upon consensus of solution. Documentation Impact ==================== To be determined References ========== History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Zed - Introduced

commit_message:
[workload_launch] Update µversions for Wallaby & Yoga

The microversions are key to ensuring that the workload
testing works whether the Undercloud has been upgraded
or not. These are set to ensure that we do all workload
testing at the source version.

Microversions are updated for:

 - Nova [a]
 - Cinder [b]
 - Manila [c]

[a] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html
[b] https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/contributor/api_microversion_history.html
[c] https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/contributor/api_microversion_history.html

Change-Id: I8fe9727570c193f96de99b812f223c7ca7dc4761
(cherry picked from commit ca284f8785186317a386a2e2ab6a0c102026e924)

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-12-12 15:18:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/0c751245df9339c48aad4efddc0b83dfc89a3fd8', 'message': 'Remove queue declaration and fix lower-constraints, docs jobs

This commit combines 3 changes:

* Remove lingering queue declaration from .zuul.yaml file

* Set upper constraint for cryptography

Lower constraint job fails due to missing flag
"X509_V_FLAG_CB_ISSUER_CHECK" while running unit test cases
```
AttributeError: module \'lib\' has no attribute \'X509_V_FLAG_CB_ISSUER_CHECK\'
```

This flag was deprecated in cryptography 37.0.0[1]

Since ceilometer doesn't have a constraint for it, the latest package
gets installed, which is 38.0.4 as of now.

This change sets cryptography to use "36.0.2" which is the last release
to have the missing x509 flag.

* Replace oslo_utils.fnmatch with fnmatch

The oslo_utils.fnmatch module was added to solve an issue in py2.7 but
it is no longer required because py2.7 is no longer supported.
The module was deprecated since oslo.utils 4.9.1[2] and the stdlib's
fnmatch module should be used instead.

[1] https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/commit/03f96199a59dff30c388142e4fbac1fc3c475041
[2] 4c893c92f551c9dd2a7cfbe7ae8171ad8139df0b

Change-Id: I9b34ac062d45b2b839dc9d6e0cdce696185890e4

to have the missing attribute.

* Replace oslo_utils.fnmatch with fnmatch

The oslo_utils.fnmatch module was added to solve an issue in py2.7 but
it is no longer required because py2.7 is no longer supported.
The module was deprecated since oslo.utils 4.9.1[2] and the stdlib's
fnmatch module should be used instead.

* Bumpup msgpack version from 0.5.0 to 0.5.2

In msgpack==0.5.0 keyword argument "raw" is not available due to which
lower-constraint job fails with error:
```
TypeError: unpackb() got an unexpected keyword argument 'raw'
```
